edge: Marlon Wayans' character, Malcolm Johnson, drives his possessed girlfriend Kisha to the hospital after a violent altercation. The fight becomes intense, and Kisha breathes into Malcolm's cousin Ray's face, causing him to pass out while driving.
After the traumatic incident with Kisha, Malcolm moves in with his girlfriend Megan and her family. The two have a relationship, but no further details about their connection are provided.
Megan is the mother of Becky, a teenage daughter who is described as bratty and promiscuous. The relationship between the two women is not further elaborated upon.
Megan also has a son named Wyatt, who is described as effeminate. The film provides no additional information about their relationship.
The family's dog, Shiloh Jr., is mentioned in the context of the movers hanging a safe next to the lawn. After the safe falls on the dog and crushes him, Malcolm dramatically cries.

The film grossed $17.3 million in North America and $8 million in other countries, for a worldwide total of $25.3 million, indicating its success at the box office.
The film received criticism from critics with a rating of 8% on Rotten Tomatoes and a score of 17 out of 100 on Metacritic, indicating poor critical reception.
The film is a horror-comedy sequel to the 2013 film 'A Haunted House'.
The film was initially scheduled for release on January 18, 2014.
The film was later pushed back to April 18, 2014.
The film's final release date was March 28, 2014.

The reviewer from Film.com gave the film a one out of ten, saying 'There are almost no redeeming qualities to this movie. It is bad enough to trigger an existential crisis in the heartiest of movie-lovers.'

The reviewer from Film.com gave the film a one out of ten, saying 'There are almost no redeeming qualities to this movie. It is bad enough to trigger an existential crisis in the heartiest of movie-lovers.' However, the reviewer from St. Louis Post-Dispatch gave the film three out of five stars, saying 'This send-up of current horror movies is a go-for-broke hoot, a hot mess of a comedy that doesn't have a lick of sense. And knowing that going in adds to the often knee-slapping laughs.'

The reviewer from The Globe and Mail gave the film zero stars out of four, saying 'A Haunted House 2 is dumber than dumb dumb, which at least has the nerve to be unapologetically dumb. Worse, it's Wayans dumb.'

The reviewer from The Hollywood Reporter gave the film a negative review, saying 'Wayans' performance again relies primarily on mugging it up and outrageous attempts at self-indulgent humor to elicit laughs, topped with copious doses of raunchy sexual innuendo and activity.'

And knowing that going in adds to the often knee-slapping laughs.'

The reviewer from Entertainment Weekly gave the film a D, saying 'You don't walk into a movie like A Haunted House 2 expecting anything remotely scary or serious, but you don't expect to walk out feeling a terrible sense of dread, either.'

The reviewer from The A.V. Club compares 'A Haunted House 2' to a 'bad festival-circuit art film'. This suggests that although the movie is still poorly received, it is an improvement over its predecessor as it is less dull and slow.
The reviewer from The A.V. Club highlights Marlon Wayans' limited comic skills as a weakness in the movie.
